Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Novel Material System and Design for Thermal Management of Asphalt Pavements
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is create a new material system of pavements for maintenance saving, safety enhancement, and lifetime extension. The material system can be integrated into a wide range of potential pavement applications from parking lots, to highway ramps, and driveways. The potential customer includes general managers or ground service managers of commercial and residential buildings with large parking lots, officials at the Department of Transportation and Department of Public Works, and even homeowners with driveways. The successful adoption of the technology may result in reducing snow removal costs, reducing parking lots/roads/highways maintenance costs, and lessening accident rates in snowy or icy conditions in winter. The technology may also be used to potentially mitigate pavement distresses due to high temperatures, thereby extending the lifespan of roads and other infrastructure.

This I-Corps project is to identify the market and establish the novel pavement technology for commercialization and technology transfer. Inspired by human skin, the proposed asphalt pavement system utilizes solar and geothermal energy to regulate the surface temperature, at which the materials can exhibit the better performance. Asphalt pavements can be damaged or degraded by various weather conditions. To address these challenges, this project develops a multifunctional material system for self-heating and cooling, performance monitoring, self-sensing, and self-healing of asphalt pavements. The system consists of heat exchange loops buried in pavement overlays, which will be heated or cooled using geothermal and solar energy via circulating thermal fluids. The heat collected and stored underground in summer will be used in winter. Carbon nanotube modified foamed asphalt has been developed for better thermal conductivity and strength.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our proposed work is a novel heating and cooling system. It targets heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) contractors who serve residential homes and small-size commercial buildings (e.g., banks, nursing homes), while the ultimate end user is homeowners who have high electric bills and want to save on their cost or are just interested in clean and renewable sources of energy for heating and cooling and who want systems with low maintenance cost. Currently, it is challenging for HVAC contractors to access ductwork of the forced-air HVAC system for retrofitting projects due to the existing structures in the houses/buildings. Residential HVAC contractors also prefer HVAC equipment that is easy to install and a faster turnaround. Last but not least, they would love reasonably priced systems with higher efficiency to attract more consumers (i.e. homeowners).

Based on the collected data from 120+ interviews conducted during the NSF I-Corps program, we found that many of the homeowners? complaints about their HVAC system are about the high electricity cost due to low efficiency, uneven heating/cooling in the house causing a hot/cold spots, and not having enough airflow from their system. On the other hand, the home builders and contractors have to deal with the waste of usable space due to ductwork while alternatives such as radiant heat installations are very costly and labor-intensive. To overcome the shortcomings of these existing technologies, we are developing an innovative bi-directional, passive heat exchange system that is easy to install and offers a more efficient and comfortable indoor heating and cooling of residential homes. The key differentiators of our technology from the conventional HVAC systems (e.g. forced air furnace, radiant heat) are that our system consumes less energy to operate yet offers higher efficiency and is faster to install. The novel heating & cooling technology we are developing is 1.5 to 2 times faster to install due to ductless configuration and running on geothermal energy as a fossil-free source. The final product will have a 20% installation cost-saving and 50% operational cost saving compared with the common forced-air system

In addition, the maintenance cost for the geothermal well and the wall panels are expected to be fairly low over their lifetime as they have no mechanical parts. Our technology addresses the aforementioned challenges and preferences that the residential HVAC contractors have; meanwhile it also brings such benefits to the end-users as a lower monthly electric bill, multizone temperature control, space-saving, dust-free, easy maintenance, and even temperature distribution in each room. On a large scale, our technology will help reduce the energy consumption for home heating and cooling and therefore the greenhouse gas emissions towards a greener and more sustainable living environment for humankind.

Furthermore, the recent experience of going through the COVID-19 pandemic showed the deficiencies of the current common central air conditioning systems in the residential and commercial houses, in which the air is circulated through ductwork in all the shared spaces and rooms. This could be of great hazard when there is an airborne virus such as Coronavirus existing in just one of the rooms and could result in the distribution of the diseases in all the other rooms of the unit/building. Therefore, the proposed system where each room is heated/cooled separately without any air circulation seems to be of great necessity to overcome the issues of transferring diseases in the existing HVAC systems.
